newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian Treasury sees CPI test as jobless falls.
newsitem.headline: Australian Treasury sees CPI test as jobless falls.

text.p: Australian Treasury Secretary Ted Evans said on Monday the real test for Australia's ability to hold down inflation would emerge when unemployment began falling, as it is forecast to over the coming year.

When Evans noted in a Senate committee that unemployment had been stagnant for about 18 months, Labor senator Nick Sherry suggested that Treasury nonetheless expected unemployment to fall at some stage.
Evans responded: "That's right. And that's where the real challenge on inflation, where the real test, will be."
Treasury has forecast a one percent year-average rise in the consumer price index (CPI) in the 1997/98 (July-June) fiscal year, compared with a forecast rise of 1.25 percent in the 1996/97 year.
It expects unemployment to fall to 8.0 percent by the end of the 1997/98 fiscal year, from an average of 8.75 percent in 1996/97.

On May 23, the Reserve Bank of Australia, which says it sets monetary policy according to signs of future inflation, cut interest rates for the fourth time in less than a year, reducing the official cash rate by 0.5 percentage point to 5.5 percent.
